Mike Stone @mike 2019-10-12 19:05

@randynose I remember it. I wonder why the unified device isn't more of a thing. I'd guess the majority of computer owners don't actually need a full blown computer. It's just nice to have a keyboard and mouse sometimes. If all phones had a desktop interface, it feels like they could easily fill that niche, especially with more and more of them USB-C now. That's what I was using to have keyboard, mouse, and monitor with sound in a single connection. Worked great. UI could use some work though.

Mike Stone boosted
switching.software @switchingsoftware 2019-10-04 10:57

Hi Fediverse üëã

let me sum up the situation around #switchingsocial

Around September 20th, the original (anonymous) author of switching.social shut down its website and all related Social Media accounts, including mastodon ü§î

This info reached me (@tobias ) the next day via my German version @swisode .

As there hasn't been any sign of life since then, I restored the website and created this new account. Right now I'm out of spare time to work on it, but that'll change in a few weeks üôÇ

Mike Stone @mike 2019-10-11 19:18

@danarel@mastodon.technology Unknown. The original author was anonymous, but all accounts and the site was shut down around the 20th of September. Since then, @tobias has mirrored the page on https://switching.software. Apparently he's gotten the endorsement of the original swithcing.social author, as the shuttered switching.social Twitter account has "Visit Switching.Software" in it's header. Hopefully @switchingsoftware will be able to maintain the list going forward.

Sean Tilley @sean 2019-10-11 00:13
Due to the extreme emergency mode my life is going into, I can no longer afford to host or maintain VidCommons.org. In case you don't recall, VC is a PeerTube instance serving as a library of Public Domain and Creative Commons media for the fediverse, kind of like what Open Audio is for Funkwhale.

If anyone is interested in transferring ownership to continue running the project, please let me know in short order! Otherwise, the instance will be discontinued at the end of next week.

#VidCommons #PeerTube #PublicDomain #Creativecommons

Gina @Gina 2019-10-10 08:41

#FOSS update. I just had a session with colleagues about #LibreOffice / #Collabora compatibility issues. It's pretty dire. Formatting in Word docs is regularly erased, Excel sheets are seeing strange bugs, and Powerpoints especially are completely ruined.

I'm wondering what the best and most time efficient way is to tackle these issues. Do we post on forums waiting for a response, do we submit tickets with Collabora, or do we find consultants from the LibreOffice community to help us out?

In honor of World Mental Health day and our organisation's focus on #selfcare, I've opened a new channel in our Rocketchat called "How are you?" It's meant to give coworkers a judgement-free place to talk about how they are doing, how work is going, how we can help each other, how the organisation can facilitate selfcare better etc.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-10-03 18:38

@JackieLibre @mikestone It really depends on your opinion of voice assistants in general. While I like Mycroft, it's not on par with any of the big proprietary offerings. It's improving rapidly though. I really like the voice assistants. I do find that the majority of the time I'm doing mundane things with them that could easily be done a different way. It's just what's convenient. If you're interested, I'd recommend one of these with Mycroft to start:

https://aiyprojects.withgoogle.com/voice/

Mike Stone @mike 2019-10-03 17:17

@grainloom It is self hostable, but there's no out of the box setup for it. There's a couple back end solutions if you're wanting to give it a go..

https://github.com/MycroftAI/personal-backend
https://github.com/MycroftAI/selene-backend

I don't know the difference between those, and I've never used either. I know there's an official roadmap from the Mycroft company itself on getting a back end server released, but it's pretty out of date and it's Google Docs, so bleh.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1VJsk9xmFig1qAP-wH_SAB-3xyKRx28Z47IwlJWJMqOM/edit?usp=sharing

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-19 18:32

@Twelve Tab stacking is a really cool feature. I use it quite a bit too. I'm not a fan of having multiple windows/browsers open, so I just lump all of it together. Grouping, and especially the ability to name/color code those groups, would be huge for my organization.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-19 18:17

It's rare I see a feature in Chrome that I want in Vivaldi, but tab grouping is definitely one of them. In the past, I've talked about just how horrible I am about keeping dozens upon dozens of tabs open at a time. I've been getting better, but right now I've got 26 open on my desktop, and 38 on my phone. This feature would be GREAT for me.

"Google releases Chrome 77 with custom colors and tab groups"

https://www.cnet.com/news/google-releases-chrome-77-with-custom-colors-and-tab-groups/

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-17 17:59

@designlibre I can undo the suspension. That's no problem. In the future, please make posts in English. Also, we don't mind automated posts, but the account needs to be active in the community. Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-17 17:31

@designlibre Sorry about the delayed response. It appears that account was suspended last month. Fosstodon is an English instance, and the account was making non-English posts (I'm not the one that worked the ticket, so I don't have the details). Attempts were made to contact the email address associated with the account to resolve the issue which received no response. Further, the account was automated with no community interaction. When no response was received, the account was suspended.

mkb @mkb 2019-09-11 16:14

OK, #Keybase users and #cryptocurrency folks, what do we think of Stellar and wallet integration with Keybase? I must confess my first response is this may be the beginning of the end for Keybase.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-11 16:19

@mkb I actually kind of like it. I looked into crypto a while back, and setup a wallet and all that stuff, but the process was NOT obvious. Having a product like Keybase, which already makes encryption their business, handle all the minutia makes sense to me. That's not to say that I'm going to start using crypto currency for everything, but it's nice to know an easy to use option is there.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-09 14:46

@blunaxela It's a really interesting solution for people that are interested in owning one of the "big" assistants but are concerned about privacy issues. I might have to get one!

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-09 14:38

@kev Then Mycroft is a great solution for you! The "Picroft" version is compatible with the Google AIY Voice Kit (which is all hardware so don't let the "Google" part throw you off"). Instead of listening all the time, it's got a button that you push when you want to talk to it. Most of the benefits, none of the listening to you all the time.

https://thepihut.com/products/google-aiy-voice-kit-premium-case-solid-blue

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-09 14:27

@stevenroose The trick about this kind of technology is that it's actually LESS intrusive than the screens we currently use. Rather than burying their nose in some screen to read the news or look up some fact, they ask an actual question in the language they speak, and they get an answer. Then they go about their business. The aim here is to make the technology we already have more accessible but less obtrusive. Done right, it's virtually invisible.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-09 14:22

@poperigby I appreciate the effort.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-08 02:28

@stevenroose How about giving access to all the information available on the Internet to people who have visual handicaps or can't read? Or reducing the learning curve for communicating with technology to a method humans have been employing for thousands upon thousands of years? Or just easing the use of technology for people who have physical handicaps or are just using their hands for something else at the time? I can see lots of value in these devices.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-07 23:55

@codesections On first read, I thought you typoed C#, and I was sitting here thinking, "Wasn't that only created around the turn of the century?"

I need more caffeine.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-07 23:53

@skarabrae I suppose that's true, but what is the timeline we're talking about here? It's not something that would have a significant impact in a week, or even a year, and it could be resolved with something as simple (and non-privacy-impacting) as a software update. If you want to keep the system offline indefinitely, it could cause issues over time though, sure. At least with the present level of technology. Eventually, improvements in AI may make it possible to adapt to those shifts.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-07 21:18

@skarabrae In the case of Mycroft at least, all interaction with outside services is anonymised, and being included in the DeepSpeech data set is opt in. My only complaint with Mycroft at this point is that you're required to go through their servers, and that's something they're working on. They've committed to personal servers, and eventually you'll be able to run the entire thing offline, on prem, and have complete control over any and all data involved.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-07 21:06

@kev Does a device listening in constantly bother you, or just a device you don't control? If you control everywhere that device goes to and how anonymous that device is with the services it employs, does that still make you feel weird about it?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-07 21:04

@skarabrae Mycroft partners with Mozilla for that. Their data sets are admittedly not as large as what's available to Google and Amazon, but they're working on it. Plus, the more support they get from the community grows those data sets, improving their capabilities.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-07 20:29

@kev The whole concept? How so?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-07 20:28

@skarabrae I would agree that there's massive potential for abuse, which is why I'm rooting for an open source solution. The current major players in the market are motivated to abuse the system. A product like Mycroft is not. One way or another, I think this kind of a product is inevitable. Being able to communicate with technology the way we communicate with people just has too many benefits.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-07 20:11

@alcinnz How is Julius? I looked at it briefly, but didn't take it too seriously because it hasn't seen an update in over 5 years.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-09-07 02:20

I think it's important to have a Free alternative, or people that want to take advantage of this kind of technology will have no options.

"The next great platform shift is underway, and that could be really bad for privacy"

https://www.privateinternetaccess.com/blog/2019/09/the-next-great-platform-shift-is-underway-and-that-could-be-really-bad-for-privacy/

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-20 23:26

@thenomad "*Well*" is probably pretty relative, since I'm just learning how to do this stuff. I'm guessing if you've used it at all, you know a few things about it I don't. How do you use it in your environment?

"DOD Sponsors Artificial Intelligence Competition"

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-15 18:03

@mysticmode Hm, are these accounts on your own instance, or other instances? Also, I'm adding @kev to this to see if he's got any ideas.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-14 20:12

@zeh Because it's not just something that affects big corporations. Bias in data sets affects small initiatives even more than it does these big corporations. For example, Mycroft AI.

https://mycroft.ai/blog/hey-mycroft-listen-to-me/

I can't say for certain, because I have no source backing this up, but I'd imagine that smaller projects like Mycroft probably have MORE of an issue with bias than larger corporations, simply because these large corporations have access to more people.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-14 19:05

@nicd There's a couple variations.

One is a bot that automatically follows thousands and thousands of people and uses its profile to serve up advertising for products or services. Often adult content is served that way.

There's another type that we've been seeing here in the Fediverse where a single bot controls thousands of accounts and mass follows people, causing an account to be spammed by follows. These are also often used for advertising or trolling.

@fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-14 15:11

@art Usually something like this, but with my hands actually on the keyboard.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-13 18:11

This is a problem with our existing data sets. Humans create the sets of data that are used by these AIs, which allows even unconscious biases to be carried over to the AIs. We need to diversify the populations that are represented in these data sets, but that's easy to say harder to do apparently.

"Google‚Äôs Hate Speech-Detecting AI is Biased Against Black People"

https://futurism.com/the-byte/google-hate-speech-ai-biased

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-09 03:10

@opal@pl.wowana.me I felt I was very specific, but I'm more than happy to have @kev fill in any blanks when he wakes up. As I stated (and you seemed to have ignored), we will block instances that are intentionally hosting illegal content (such as child porn) if it's brought to our attention. We're not seeking these sites out. I'm fully aware we can simply drop their media, but as I stated unequivocally, we want nothing to do with that. Hopefully @kev can clarify where I've failed to make our position clear.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-09 03:04

@librelounge Ahh, that makes sense. Nope, I'm just some rando that heard your latest episode on managing spam and hate speech and decided to follow you.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-09 02:59

@opal@pl.wowana.me This position is explained on our Instance Block disclosure page under the "Why so much silence" header.

https://hub.fosstodon.org/instance-block-list

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-09 02:57

@opal@pl.wowana.me This is our policy. Most of the time, we try to silence instances if their content is questionable and/or they're not using CWs for adult content. We recognize that our community contains adults. We won't block them from accessing legal material if they should want to view it. When it comes to material that is illegal, we will block that if it's brought to our attention. That's ESPECIALLY true where the instance focuses on that material intentionally. Hosting child porn is not OK.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-09 02:41

@opal@pl.wowana.me Because "Lolicon" is basically child pornography. It's of questionable legality in some countries due to its animated nature. In other countries, such as the UK where @kev is from, it's just flat out illegal. We want nothing to do with that.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-07 19:33

@MatejLach To me, that's an argument for NOT opening up the source. If it's developed privately (or even by a single corporation), the damage done to living entities is limited. Even with laws in place people will mistreat these AIs as they already do with people. It would be infinitely worse without laws in place.

@ataraxia937 @louwestin

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-07 00:08

@ataraxia937 Perfectly coherent, even if you've had a couple.

There's an argument to be made that BECAUSE we may all die from an ecological/climate disaster we NEED to focus on AI. I don't remember where I read it, but someone postulated that all that will remain of all intelligent races will be the AIs they created.

@louwestin

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-06 23:58

@dyamon It's an interesting question. Assuming we could, should we?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-06 23:49

@mplammers I think this conversation would be fine to be unmasked, I just know that philosophical discussions can be annoying for some people, so I CWed it just in case.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-06 23:47

@louwestin No, that ship has sailed already. It's my belief that AI is here, and it's only going to get more and more advanced. My questions are more about what do we do when it's here? I'm asking because I think we need to be ready.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-06 23:38

@cathal The problem is that we, as a society, do not have any rules or protections in place for created individuals of a non-biological nature. If an self aware, living AI were created tomorrow, should it's creator make its code available to everybody without restriction? As @sheogorath asked, do we even have the right to do that in the first place?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-06 23:33

@deejoe It appears to me at least that there are moral arguments to be made on both sides. Can we as a society "allow" everybody to have the ability to do this? I don't know. Do we have the right to do it in the first place, as @sheogorath pointed out earlier? I don't know that either.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-06 21:53

@sheogorath That's a very good point! I've heard many people complain about privacy aspects of DNA sharing. An Uncle of mine was concerned that I'd done 23andMe because of the DNA we share exposes him. And that's just information (at least at present). What would people think if someone else published the ability to replicate them down to the last detail at will?

@louwestin

Mike Stone boosted
Sheogorath @sheogorath 2019-08-06 21:39

@mike

Isn't there even the ethical question that if one figures out a alive artificial intelligence that it has a right to privacy and not being open sourced at its own will?

Nowadays you would run into a lot of legal trouble when you "open source" someone's complete DNA without their consent. And you as well as me would be quite uncomfortable when someone else would make such a decision about our own DNA.

@louwestin

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-06 21:49

@louwestin So I guess the question is, should we TRY to stop it?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-06 21:45

@lukedashjr There's no control over whether people have children or not, but there absolutely is oversight regarding how those children are treated. The same can not be said for any form of artificial life.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-06 21:33

@lukedashjr There have been laws to protect people and animals for as long as there has been society.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-06 21:29

@MatejLach I think the use of the word "ownership" is interesting. If this AI is by any measure alive and conscious, wouldn't ownership of one of these AIs be basically slavery? Even having one living in your home could be considered unlawful imprisonment. The alternate of open sourcing the ability to create an artificial life isn't ownership of those AIs by a select few corporations. It's containment of the technology (at least temporarily).

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-06 21:19

@wizzwizz4 I love your optimism!

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-06 21:18

@brandon Technically not true, but I don't think that anybody thinks that Sophia is actually a real living being. If Sophia accidentally (or purposefully) took a tumble down 7 flights of stairs, do you think anybody would be charged with a crime? That distinction is PR, not policy.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-06 21:09

@louwestin I'm not aware of any existing regulations regarding artificial life and the treatment of those individuals. You're are correct that there will always be those who violate regulations, but in this case the source is controlled, and those individuals don't have access. Would it be more ethical to give everybody the ability to create artificial life by opening the source, or keep it controlled and out of the reach of those with good and bad intentions alike?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-06 21:01

@wizzwizz4 At present, no artificial life has rights. Not to delve too deeply into politics, but government in any form hasn't been super quick to respond to new scenarios. How long do you think it would take for those rights to be recognized?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-06 20:50

@rumblestiltskin@mastodon.technology That's a good question. There's a discussion to be had about whether anybody should be trusted with this ability. There's a whole other conversation about whether EVERYBODY should have that ability if any single individual does.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-08-06 20:48

@darth_tiktaalik Kinda. There are laws about the treatment of humans and animals. There are none regarding the treatment of a life form that isn't biological in nature.

@brainblasted Not to put too fine of a point on it, but Fosstodon was created so people would have a place to discuss technology, specifically around Free/Libre Open Source Software. Complaining that we would like to keep our subject matter in that general area is like complaining you can't buy 40 2x4s at Barnes and Noble. If you wanted to talk about your experience with racism, please use a CW. If you want to discuss how inherent bias in data sets causes a racism problem for AI, that's fine.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-07-29 18:17

@geezyx They really should. I had a bit of warning because my wife got called maybe a month before my first time, and she was caught off guard. @ndegruchy

Mike Stone @mike 2019-07-29 18:15

@louwestin It's more general than that. It sees you as a series of data points, which is how corporations see you as well. Mike Stone @mike 2019-07-29 18:07

Mike Stone @mike 2019-07-24 23:08

@simon Welcome back!

Mike Stone @mike 2019-07-24 22:59

@kelbot The non-male voice is a major issue, but it's something Mycroft can do very little about. They need to train their model, and to do that they need data. Besides hiring women and children to come in and talk, I'm not sure how they can generate the data they need.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-07-24 22:57

@kelbot They have 3 voices, and they have an option to use Google's version, so I guess that makes it 4. The original AP voice (which I use on my Mark I), an "American Female", which isn't technically that great, and the new "American Male" version, which i use on my ThinkPad. That one is actually really good, but it doesn't compare to Google's 11 choices which offer a wide variety. It's my understanding these voices are relatively inexpensive to generate, so why not have more?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-07-24 22:21

@kelbot I sure hope so. I'd hate to see it get this far and vanish. There are also things they can do that would help them out. Additional voices for example. They're relatively inexpensive, and they give the end user a more personalized feel. Especially now when each individual Mycroft unit in your house can have a different configuration. I leave the traditional AP voice on my Mark I and the new voice is what I use on my ThinkPad.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-07-24 20:49

@GreyLinux Yea, that's been my biggest complaint with them. They market what their goals are, not what they've actually got, and then after they've made the sale they try to build what they wanted. On top of that, they've got big goals. There are still things in the Mark I Kickstarter video that the current incarnation of Mycroft can't do. That's frustrating. I still support them because I like these kinds of devices, I don't like them spying on me, and Mycroft leads the FLOSS market offerings.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-07-24 20:42

@kelbot Yea, I'm a little concerned with their current trajectory. They're developing based on the RaspPi, which is fine in and of itself, but the Pi was the basis for the Mark I so unless they're planning on standardizing on the Pi4, there's going to be almost no performance upgrade for the new devices. That's a problem because the Mark I is SLOW. Add to that the "finite budget" bit, and there's a lot to be concerned about. I wish they'd open source their backend to allow on prem functionality.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-07-24 19:58

I love Mycroft but I wish they'd develop a product and have it ready before they start selling it. They're still trying to get the Mark II working, and it was supposed to have shipped last December. Still, they're the best player in the open source assistant market, and I feel like they deserve our support. There are several ways to help out, many that don't involve money. If you can, please do.

"Real Companies Ship Product - Mycroft"

https://mycroft.ai/blog/real-companies-ship-product/

Mike Stone @mike 2019-07-24 16:52

@pranav Kinda sometimes. I'm not a "real" developer, but I support our production servers and process automation and monitoring is part of the deal. Because of that, I sometimes write custom little scripts that pull data from databases, or move files around the system. It's not real "development" work, but I do on occasion write code. Basic code, but still code.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-07-05 23:38

Mike Stone @mike 2019-07-05 23:37

@ataraxia937 I can't speak for Gab as I know nothing about how that system operates, but for Twitter there's a wizard when you sign in for the first time that makes suggestions. Librem One may have a problem with that as they don't have an equivalent feature as of yet, but they can still use the Trunk if they so choose. I don't think they're making that known, so it could be difficult for first time users.

https://communitywiki.org/trunk

Mike Stone @mike 2019-07-05 23:33

@jordan31 They're like lists on Twitter. You create them add other people to them. You decide how they're grouped, and you can add them as their own column in the multi-column view. For example, I have one called Moderators. As far as I can tell though, and I hope someone will correct me if I'm wrong, they're always private.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-07-05 23:30

@kelbot True, I didn't see that part. I can see wanting an assistant with comparable functionality, but actually running their software, no.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-07-05 23:01

https://hackaday.io/project/164221-smart-speaker-from-scratch

Mike Stone @mike 2019-06-19 03:52

@jordan31 Not according to their Privacy Policy.

https://keybase.io/docs/privacypolicy

Also, Keybase is nice in that it works as a traditional key store. By you knowing that my account here on Fosstodon is verified to my Keybase.io account, you can retrieve my public key. Also, if you're using their services as well, they have end to end encrypted file shares, as well as encrypted git repos. It really is a nice service.

@blaubachn

Mike Stone @mike 2019-06-16 08:55

@kev One benefit I've seen that not a single app has is access to the moderation interface. You can handle reports from the web interface, but you can't from FediLab, or Toot, or Tusky. That gives it a boost as far as I'm concerned.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-06-10 15:14

Is it weird I've been enjoying the gymnastics Apple fans have been doing trying to excuse that $1000 monitor stand? I read one this morning that noted that 50.87% of Twitter comments were positive about the monitor, so the majority. While that's absolutely true, 50.87% IS a majority, I wonder how that compares to other Apple announcements, and how much of that 50.87% was people trying to excuse the $1000 stand. At the end of it all, it doesn't matter much, but still, it's funny to me.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-06-10 15:10

@pranav Good advice. I did took it and I feel much better this morning. That's good because I get to do it all over again today.

Woohoo.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-06-05 00:07

@sean @mdbekhit My browsers are all configured to reopen in previous state, so even a shutdown or a loss of power doesn't lose the tabs that I currently have open. I acknowledge that my way is not a good way to do it. It's sloppy and uses a lot of system resources. I just find when I do bookmark things, those bookmarks go stale fast and I lose track of what I have in them. When I'm done with something, I close the tab. If I need it again, DDG to the rescue.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-06-04 23:56

@sean @mdbekhit I have very few web-based apps open at any given time. Right now, I have Fosstodon and Feedly. Everything else I've got open is a standard site of some kind. I could bookmark the site and come back to it later, but I almost never bookmark anything.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-06-04 23:31

@letthewatersroar@toot.cafe It happens naturally to be honest. I use tabs instead of bookmarks for the most part. Tabs stay open until I'm done with whatever I was doing on that tab. I sometimes use Vivaldi's Tab Stacks to group tabs with similar subjects (good for researching stuff) to conserve space on my screen. Because of the way I use my browser, my bookmarks are almost entirely unused. The ones I do have are relics that have been there forever and I have no idea how they got in there.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-06-04 18:50

Background: We're connecting to a client's FTP for file transfer.

Us: If it's FTP we're going to need to encrypt, so please send us your key.
Them: Here's the key.
Them: Hey, can we host on your site instead?
Us: Sure, let's get it setup.
Us: *setup site* *go to install key*
Us: Hey, can you send us your PGP key? This is your public SSH key.
Them: Why didn't you specify?

Uh, why in the hell would you send us your public ssh key to encrypt files when we're connecting to your server?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-06-04 17:01

@utf8equalsX @delta I'm not actually sure for certain. PGP has it's own integrated compression, but for extremely low values, that's not helpful. 10 characters still comes out as hundreds. Thousands are reduced to lower numbers, but I'm not sure where the tipping point is. I don't think it's within normal Mastodon range though.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-06-04 16:45

@neildarlow Oh yea, I have a Mycroft instance running in the background, and I had Vivaldi running with at least 24 open tabs (@kev has made fun of me in the past for the massive number of tabs I leave open) and at least 12 active extensions. I probably had Firefox open at the time too, and more than likely Rhythmbox. I wasn't being frugal about my resources let's just say.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-22 16:39

@anand So there's the standard common emoji that everybody has, and there's the custom instance based emoji. Those are emoji like :fosstodon: that are instance only. When you use them, they get sent, so people on other instances see the emoji you've sent and you can see theirs, but you can't use emoji from other instances and they can't use ours. That being said, there is an option for an administrator to copy emoji from other instances, so if you see something you want, ask.

@fosstodon @Tusky

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-22 16:21

@mikestone :fosstodon:

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-22 03:38

@mooshoe
There's actually potential for this to backfire on Google. By yanking the licence, it shows just how tenable if a position any OEM is in who uses Google's OSs. It may behoove competing platforms to join forces to create an organization whose responsibility it is to develop a forked version of Android from the OSAP, compete with a distinct software store.

I'm not holding my breath on this happening, but the potential is there at least.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-22 03:07

Jonny doesn't seem to grasp that for a social network to be successful, it can't be locked into a platform, and by tying it to Apple services, it's guaranteed failure. Ignoring that, it's easy to point out that Google had everything Apple has and more, yet they still failed with Google+.

"Apple has a chance to build a social network we can trust"

https://www.computerworld.com/article/3396996/apple-has-a-chance-to-build-a-social-network-we-can-trust.html

#introduction

Hi! I found Mastodon through a New Yorker article ("What it Takes to Put Your Phone Away").

I have a degree that uniquely qualifies me for precisely nothing. So, I am teaching myself to program for a chance at a real career (also for fun!).

Mastodon fits nicely into my desire for a world that will move away from systems optimizing for profit and toward systems that optimize for wellbeing. I think our economy and its metrics need updating.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-21 00:15

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-21 00:13

@toshioxgnu Yep, Mastodon itself is open source, so you can grab the code and do with it what you will. It's also federated, which means you can create your own instance if you like. It works kind of like a Twitter/email mix. There's no "master node", and because it uses a standardized protocol to federate, it can communicate with other platforms as well, like PixelFed and PeerTube. Pretty cool stuff in my opinion.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-21 00:10

@kev You've got this.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-20 16:59

@zaid The first job I had was driving truck on my uncle's farm. My first tech job was desktop support. My first job after I finished college was doing automated credit approvals using a proprietary programming language that belonged to the company I worked for.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-19 07:44

@zaid Well, obviously it depends on the job. Research the company you're working for, and look at all the requirements of the position. They will usually have a "required" and a "desired" sections. Make sure you're able to talk with knowledge about any of those subjects (not just superficially either), and you're probably going to do alright. Of course, there's never any guarantees, but that's the best advice I've been given.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-19 01:56

@DistroJunkie
Oddly, I've had the opposite experience. I doubt this is common, and it may just be an error on the part of my eye doctor at some point, but I started needing glasses about the time I turned 10. Then in my late 20s my eyes began getting progressively better. Not perfect. I still need glasses, but my prescription is getting less and less. At this rate, if I live to be 200, I may not need glasses anymore!

* curl or browser interface
* 56 programming languages
* several DBMSes
* 1000+ UNIX commands
* CLI interface too (cht.sh)
* Use directly from code editors

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-17 17:58

@zaid The career has been alright. I work on all RHEL servers for a really large corporation, but usually the work is pretty boring. All of our hardware is virtualized now, and I don't have any interaction with it.

I started using Linux in college as a programming environment. Our college used Digital Unix on their servers, and Linux was a good approximation for the programming environment that I could use at home. That way I didn't have to be constantly dialed in to the Internet. Love it.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-16 20:33

@nicd Yes, you can. If you click on the ... next to the Favourite on one of your own posts, the menu that comes up should have an option called "Delete & re-draft". This essentially removes the post from the timeline and populates the new post field with the contents of that toot. That way you can "edit" what you said and re-post it. I'm not sure that's what you're seeing, but it sounds suspiciously like it, especially if the changes are small.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-16 20:25

@nicd It's no problem. So, it's not a duplicate post, but the same post moves back to the top? Are you sure they're not using the delete & re-draft option?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-16 20:18

@nicd Does it stay if you refresh the page? Is it doing it in multiple browsers?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-16 20:04

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-10 22:37

@thenomad Not a competition, just a conversation with a friend at work. She said she could do a particular task in 4 lines of code, I said I could do it in one. She declared that using pipes is "cheating" and each command should count as a new line. I thought I'd ask the community to see what the consensus was on that claim.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-10 22:14

So, semantics question.

Is using a pipe technically a "new" line of code, or can you pipe over and over again in a single line and it's technically still a single line of code?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-09 18:06

@neildarlow They wouldn't be wrong about the underlying structure of Windows. Around the turn of the century when Apple moved from "Classic" MacOS to it's current "Unixy" base, I thought Microsoft might follow suit and move Windows to a Linux based system. They've been proving me wrong for the better part of two decades now, so I'm not going to hold my breath on that move. Still, it would be a good move for them I think.

@inknos It's still significantly slower than an Echo or Google Home, but the performance has improved. It also depends greatly on the hardware it's running on. Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-03 20:58

@pvols1979 I don't know of a good way to do that within Mastodon. I've always used a 3rd party service like https://fediverse.network to find out how many peers each server has. You can theoretically look in the Moderation and Federation section of your Administrator stuff, but it doesn't give hard numbers, just a list. There are a lot of instances, so if you're connected to a large number of them, that isn't going to be useful.

@ashfurrow@mastodon.technology

Mike Stone boosted
Gina @Gina 2019-05-03 16:38

You didn't think that I would forget about #NameAndFame Friday, did you? So many #FOSS / #opensource software makers deserve a shoutout.

This week, take a look at Apache Guacamole: https://guacamole.apache.org/ Guacamole is a clientless remote desktop gateway, supporting standard protocols like VNC, RDP, and SSH. We hooked it up to our (virtual) Linux and Windows desktops, and now we can access them anywhere via a browser. Basically magic!

Who would you like to boost for #NameAndFame Friday?

Mike Stone boosted
Yarmo üïä @yarmo 2019-05-03 16:59

#nameandfame time, folks! Again, I've chosen an absolute daily life saver. I know there are alternatives that are less resource-intensive (but I won't double #nameandfame üòÖ), but this is still my go to.

Today, if you haven't already, take a look at #ranger, a console file manager with vi keybinding and so much more!

https://ranger.github.io/

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-03 17:32

@sean Yes, unfortunately (this is just my opinion) this is the genesis of the voice market, and it's my belief that we're going to see voice in all sorts of places going forward. If there's not an alternative to the big players, then Google and Amazon are going to be used in all these cases. In 5 years you won't be able to microwave a burrito without an alert on your phone telling you the middle is still cold. That's why I'm supporting Mycroft here and now, even though not everything is optimal.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-03 17:29

@kelbot Yep, only significantly faster. I was toying with it last night (should have taken some video of it) where I had my ThinkPad on the desk next to my Mark I, and I was asking questions. There's a dramatic difference in response time.

@RyuKurisu

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-03 17:22

@kelbot Probably a lot like it works with Gnome, meaning it has no interface in the GUI. It's running in the background, and you can activate it through voice commands, but there are no visual clues it's there.

@RyuKurisu

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-03 17:14

@simper Nope, not with Tusky. Maybe they'll add the feature in the future.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-03 16:57

@RyuKurisu It's done in the terminal at this point, but there's only a couple commands and it's really a straight forward process. Not quite "snap" easy, but pretty easy none the less. You really just have to clone a git repo, and then execute the wizard which, while based in the terminal, is just a series of yes/no questions. After that you start the services and you're off to the races. If you're interested....

https://github.com/MycroftAI/mycroft-core/blob/dev/README.md

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-03 16:47

@kelbot Fair enough.

@jonathan_knez @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-03 16:13

@kelbot I wouldn't go so far as to say "dumb", but definitely short sighted. Disabling that feature makes sense in a monolithic environment. If librem.one was a stand alone service that didn't interact with anybody else, there is no local or federated timeline, individuals blocking individuals would be sufficient. Unfortunately, they didn't think about the rest of the federation when they did it. I imagine that decision hit them like a kick in the face.

@jonathan_knez @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-03 16:08

@sean I would love to have a Jarvis, and I think that's where we're headed. Unfortunately we're not all billionaires and Jarvis doesn't run on a $35 appliance. Most people aren't willing to pay for the equipment necessary to make it work, so there's been very little driver in the market to make that infrastructure available. I think Mycroft can change that and provide an open front and back end.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-03 15:39

@sean It's worth noting also, this particular implementation "Chatterbox" doesn't record anything until a physical button is pushed on a device that you build yourself using off the shelf parts. Really, when it comes to the personal assistant market, it doesn't get more private than that at this point. If not now, in the future, Mycroft could be the standard for privacy in this market.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-03 15:37

@sean If by offsite you mean outside of your own location, then yes. They have their own Deepspeech farm. They're in the process of providing the ability for you to host your own Mycroft back end, but that hasn't been released yet. When it does, you should be able to run your entire house, complete with home automation, with no Internet connection.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-03 15:09

I love seeing this. I would like to see Mycroft or projects like it being used for more commercial applications.

"Chatterbox is a DIY Kids Smart Speaker that Features Open-Source and Private Voice Assistant, Mycroft"

https://voicebot.ai/2019/04/29/chatterbox-is-a-diy-kids-smart-speaker-that-features-open-source-and-private-voice-assistant-mycroft/

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-03 14:58

@erikstl I use an extension called Collapsed Mastodon. It adds a couple features to the default web client, including spacing the columns to match your monitor space.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-03 14:49

@erikstl You can add new ones based on hashtags or lists too. So much columny fun!

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-03 14:41

@jordan31 Thank you! I had to make that one myself. Well, I made some minor modifications to some stuff I found online. Just couldn't find anything that really fit my fancy specifically.

@DistroJunkie

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-03 14:39

@jonathan_knez And I think that's a solid strategy for Purism. These services already exist in the wild (minus the changes from their forking), so development requirements for them are minimal, yet they can offer a collection of services that are valuable to the people using them that live up to the core values of the company. I'm not super crazy about some of the ways they implemented it, but all in all I'm not going to shrill rant on a podcast about it either.

@kev @kelbot

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-02 23:21

@njha @Logical_Error It's used like a Like or a heart, but it does save that post into a special list. You can see your favorites in the Getting Started column of the web interface.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-02 20:44

@jonas How'd that go?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-02 20:42

@downey@floss.social Yea, leaving this features active in their forked version of Tusky is a serious oversight. It looks weird in the screenshots I've seen. Maybe they'll revisit. Hopefully they'll revisit.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-02 20:40

@DistroJunkie I went and listened to part of it because I was involved in this conversation, and it did seem very personal. It felt like a lot more than a product release he didn't feel was done right. That's just my impression though.

@sean

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-02 17:41

@downey@floss.social Agreed, but even for smaller instances the local timeline may not be a desirable feature. For our instances, we are specialized around specific subject matter, so we attract individuals with similar interests. For more general instances, there isn't that shared interest, so the local timeline may just be full of random junk. I can definitely see the logic in removing those feeds in the case of a general instance like librem.one. Especially if the eventual goal is a large population.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-02 15:17

@Gina The biggest complaint I hear over and over is about it's UI. I personally like it, but an option for a more simple single column UI would be a nice improvement. Something like Brutaldon would be a great option when you first create your account. Maybe a ballot screen with the standard UI and the simplified UI as options during the onboarding process?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-02 15:14

@creepermario Dunno. It's also where #Tusky got it's name and logo, in reference to the tusks of the mastodons.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-02 14:56

@murtezayesil That's interesting because (obviously) the SSD is a significant advantage. Void must have some serious mojo to even come close to competing.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-02 14:55

@codesections I know this is probably going to sound weird coming from me, because I do love our Local timeline here on Fosstodon, but I'm less concerned about removing the Local and the Fed from Librem.one. I'm unconvinced about their utility as the environment grows. Millions of users in the Fed make it impossible to follow anybody for any length of time, and the same issues arise for the Local timeline as an instance gains a significant number of users.

@brandon

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-02 14:52

@codesections I think that's a good question. If I recall correctly, when you join the birdsite, there's an initial process that suggests people to follow either from your contacts list or from other popular accounts. Mastodon doesn't have that (at least not at this point). We do have the Trunk, but it's not directly tied in, so it's not something new users would be immediately aware of.

@brandon

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-02 14:44

@murtezayesil Yea, I had Solus Budgie on my ThinkPad prior to installing Ubuntu 19.04. Ubuntu is NOTICEABLY slower in almost every aspect.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-02 14:39

@erikstl Inherently privacy respecting? I'd say there's no direct tie between FOSS and the respect of privacy. It's just as easy to violate privacy with a FOSS product as a non-FOSS app. I'd say because of it's nature that respecting your privacy is more of a "default setting" simply because most FOSS projects don't have corporate behemoth calling the shots that "needs" that information for their own purposes.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-01 22:27

@brandon Their implementation is certainly unusual. I'm hoping that this is a dry run and they'll learn from the community and make changes, but we'll have to wait and see. It has a potential of being a great thing for Mastodon. it IS very cool that a company like Purism finds Mastodon mature enough to base a product on. Now we just need it to be a good product.

When we get a report it comes through email. Obviously we can see it in the Admin interface, but no notification in Mastodon.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2019-05-01 20:34

@DistroJunkie I don't listen to the Podcast, but I wonder if that has anything to do with Lunduke. I feel like I read somewhere that they had a somewhat contentious relationship after LAS. Maybe I'm remembering that wrong, but might have played into it?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-27 04:57

@pranav In this context, the "Hi" or "Hello" grabs the attention of the person receiving the message, interrupting what was already in progress but with no further information or context provided. It's much better to include the greeting along with additional information or a request, like "Hi Pranav, I need you to do this thing for me." That does steal your attention from what you're currently working on so you can watch the "Mike Stone is currently typing..." sitting on your screen.

Mike Stone boosted
@skunksarebetter 2019-04-26 16:50

#SC (#Spreadsheet Calculator) is a public domain #terminal spreadsheet editor.

SC features Vi-esque key bindings (hjkl) but lacks modality, making it very easy to learn. < may be used to enter left-justified text, and = can be used to enter math formulae.

SC equations are like any other editor's equations, LetterNumber can be used to reference a cell, and functions like average may be used with @avg(range).

Website üîó: http://www.ibiblio.org/pub/Linux/apps/financial/spreadsheet/!INDEX.html

apt üì¶: sc

#free #opensource #foss #fossmendations

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-26 16:49

This is something that raises my hackles daily. Just don't do it!

http://www.nohello.com

Mike Stone boosted
@skunksarebetter 2019-04-26 16:44

#Nano is a small and easy to use #terminal text editor.

Nano supports only a few necessary special commands, greatly simplifying use when comparing it with Emacs or Vim.

Nano is perfect for quick note taking or program fixing, where the simple interface and instant startup has the ideal chance to shine.

Website üîó: https://www.nano-editor.org/

apt üì¶: nano

#free #opensource #foss #fossmendations #sysadmin

Gina @Gina 2019-04-26 10:55

Shall we do another #NameAndFame Friday? There are many free and/or #opensource software makers that deserve a shoutout.

This week I'd like to name #Jitsi Meet, a nice opensource videoconference tool, available via browser, on mobile and there's a desktop (Electron) app as well: https://github.com/jitsi/jitsi-meet-electron

You can use Jitsi Meet or set up your own Jitsi server. The best part is that you don't need an account to create or join a conference.

Who would you like to boost for #NameAndFame Friday?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-25 19:20

@ref209 I tried Dvorak many, MANY years ago, but that was always my problem. I kept having to go back and forth between Dvorak and standard QWERTY, and I found it was impacting my speed on both layouts. Sticking with the standard meant that I didn't have to switch and I got faster than I was. I'm not jumping around as much as I used to, so if there are tangible benefits to switching, I'm willing to give it a try.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-25 19:18

@Piejacker875 I learned to type in school, which means if I move away from a QWERTY keyboard, I've got about 30 years of muscle memory to overcome. Still, if there are tangible benefits, I'd go for it.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-25 18:33

@dansup Would love to know what they were thinking when they said the project wasn't around anymore.

There's just so many things I really like about it.

@dwc @queuedhub

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-22 03:37

@queuedhub
Well, Diaspora doesn't use the ActivityPub protocol, so they can't interact with Mastodon. They're federated with their own, fairly proprietary protocol (though I believe they've opened it, few others use it). Friendica does use ActivityPub, so it can interact with Mastodon. I'm not at a computer right now, but Friendica might also support Diaspora Federation. I'd have to double-check that.

@dwc

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-20 19:54

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-17 19:51

@piggo Ouch, and the transfer rate is horrid. Get a friend and transfer a picture between your phones using it. I doubt anybody is going to spend the required time to do a transfer of any significant size.

@jbob @kelbot

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-17 19:30

@kelbot Not to mention how long it takes to put data on one of them. They're not exactly "drop a quick file on here and go" type of media.

@jbob @piggo

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-17 19:28

@kelbot True, not to mention the fact there is already competing mediums. You'd have to compete with USB sticks that you can buy for next to nothing and the read/write times and capacities. I did a quick DDG, and you can get 1GB for $2. It would have to beat that on capacity and price to warrant the purchase of hardware that isn't already in most computers. And that's today's numbers.

@jbob @piggo

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-17 19:17

@kelbot The size isn't specifically an issue, but the amount of storage in some of the smaller form factors would be. How easily they're damaged is a big deal though.

https://www.bandcds.co.uk/all-others/business-card-cds/

@jbob @piggo

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-17 19:13

@jbob I'd say the fragility of the medium is a major reason. Especially as data density increases (which would be required for modern systems) the physical damage to the disk would have a greater and greater impact.

@kelbot @piggo

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-17 18:54

@kelbot
This reminds me of the old Iomega Clik disks. Other than the price of them (and storage capacity compared to modern day solutions), the form factor was really cool.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-13 20:21

@gnuhacker1208 When I first used Linux, the first thing it did was annoy me. It was during the first installation, and I remember it giving me an estimate for how long the install would take. It was right almost down to the minute. This annoyed me for no really good reason because I'd been working with Windows so long, and Windows either took significantly less time than it claimed it would, or a whole lot more. I had to laugh at myself for being annoyed at an OS for being correct.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-12 16:17

@eskuero@niu.moe After the 2.8.0 Mastodon upgrade, when I'm using a Chrome based browser, the reply box doesn't show up. If I click again it warns me I'm going to lose my previous reply, so it seems like the box is somewhere, but it's not visible. There's no errors or anything to help out with, but I've seen the same problem in Windows, Solus, and Mint. It does work in Firefox though on all the same computers, so it's just in Vivaldi that I'm seeing it.

Mike Stone boosted
pixelfed development @pixeldev 2019-04-11 22:48
We are aware of a regression in Pixelfed that is discarding valid ActivityPub objects. A fix will be shipped in v0.9.0 which will be released tonight. #pixelfed
Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-11 22:08

@yarmo

If you mean the Home timeline, then the answer is unfortunately no. For the Home timeline, your options are limited to showing boosts and replies or not. That's for the web UI. Other clients may give you more or less options.

It would be possible to add all the people you follow to their own list and create a column for that and hide the default home column. You could create a list for bots and a separate and distinct one for non-bots. That would require some maintenance though.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-11 21:58

@eskuero@niu.moe Works fine in Firefox though. Just doesn't work in Vivaldi (didn't test other Chromium browsers).

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-11 21:51

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-11 15:42

@jordan31 It's an encryption system made easy. It has a bunch of different services, but encryption is the main thing. They do text encryption, chat (individual and team), file sharing, git, crypto-currency, and identity verification. All encrypted end to end and made easy on a level that most people can do it, even if they're not overly technical.

dansup the creator @dansup 2019-04-07 01:04

Only 1 post on pixelfed.social has disabled comments, the test post I made.

Only 6% of users hide their follower counts.

These privacy and safety features may not be for everyone, that doesn't discourage me from adding more.

Pixelfed aims to be safer than Instagram.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-04-07 01:05

@bumbervevo I don't really use Twitter much, and when I do I use TweetDeck. There's no mobile equivalent that I'm aware of.

As far as Mastodon, it depends on what you like and the platform you're using. I use #Fedilab on my mobile, and I use the standard web interface on my computer. If you're looking for other ways to access, #Brutaldon is a minimalist interface that can even be used in a terminal interface. You can also use tootstream or bitlbee in the terminal.

Just read the monthly #Linux #Mint blog, and it's a bit disheartening. Besides updates it very honestly talks about the relation betweens devs and users, negative feedback, and on the demoralizing side of #FOSS development: https://blog.linuxmint.com/?p=3736

#Mint isn't just a great distro, it's also one of the main portals to the Linux world. I left them a nice message and a donation. Maybe others could too?

@lee8oi It was pretty common around my university. There were a lot of people I knew that would get the "60 Days Free" or "90 Days Free", and just cancel after the free period. ADP @adp 2019-03-29 18:57

Just joined! Glad to be part of this!

I discovered Mastodon after reading about the "Re-decentralizing the Internet" movement. It hit me right on the nose. Being a developer who's worked in media and ad tech, and someone with kids, I'm concerned about the direction we seem to be moving in. Joining this community is my first small step towards decentralization of my "personal infrastructure" and taking back ownership of our data and privacy.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-28 06:48

Quite literally, the post is labeled "For GENIUSES ONLY", and every single person thinks they can answer it. Obviously I'm not that bright because I still have a Facebook account, and I come from a long line of not terribly bright people because they all decided Facebook is the best place to communicate. Still, everyone thinks they're SO smart. If more people realized how little they know, the world would be a better place.

End Rant. I'm tired. Off to bed. Sorry for the rant.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-28 06:46

See, this is one of the many things wrong on Facebook. I see a post like this all the time with the caption, "For GENIUSES ONLY". Of course every single person I know is trying to answer it, but there's no single right answer.

4*1+1=5
5*2+2=12
3*6+3=21
8*5+5=45??

2+5+5=12
3+6+12=21
5+8+21=34??

Or maybe just because some idiot throws a couple wrong answers with a pattern at you doesn't change the answer from 13?

The biggest problem is this in my opinion:

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-24 03:29

@lufthans
Nope, but I do know some other options have been requested, like posts just to the local instance whether or not your instance is Federated. Gargron has traditionally fought that one. Could be someone else requested what you're looking for. If not, never hurts to put in a request!

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-24 03:15

@lufthans
Yes, like birdsite, it automatically adds all mentioned users to any reply. It's up to the person writing the reply to remove individuals he or she doesn't want to get the reply.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-24 03:12

@lufthans
Sorry, misread that. No, the OP can't.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-24 03:10

@lufthans
Sure, permissions can be changed after the reply is started. Only people specifically mentioned will get a response if you desire. Like this response that only you can see.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-24 02:59

@lufthans

You can't mute just a particular branch of a thread. You're muting the conversation, which is all branches of the thread.

Replies automatically inherit the permissions of the post the reply is to. You can change the default permissions of your posts, but not the default permissions of replies because of that. Personally I look at it as a feature, not a bug. Replies automatically honor the permissions selected by the OP.

I do know there's a LUG over in Chandler that seems pretty active that I've been tempted by in the past. Maybe now that my kids are getting older I'll look back into it. I'll look around and see if I can find more.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-23 00:17

cat filelist.ms|while read LINE
do
scp user@server.name:/path/to/file/$LINE .
gpg -r A1234BC -o $LINE.pgp -e $LINE
scp $LINE.pgp user@other.server.name:/output/path/
rm $LINE $LINE.pgp
done

Seriously, I think this is half my day. The fact that I haven't ACTUALLY scripted this is criminal.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-22 23:52

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-22 23:44

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-22 23:43

@DistroJunkie It's interesting, because I can absolutely see where, implemented a specific way), it would be awesome for a lay user. I'm imagining a series of different hardware types that basically just PXE boot to a server. That server only maintains your data statically in an encrypted state. Every piece of software would be destroyed after use, like a pod. Even the OS itself. You would always feel like you're using the same computer, but it would be fresh every time you used it. Tempting.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-22 23:26

@danjones I think you and @codesections hit my opinion right on the head. In theory I can see where it might be attractive to non-technical people who have no real interest in a computer, but for it to fly for me I'd want to have control. I feel the same way about these smart assistants. I like the idea, but I hate that every sound in my house is getting beamed out onto the Internet for who knows who to listen to. Having all the processing local would be a much better solution in my mind.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-22 23:22

@s3rvant I'd be interested in that as well, but not with the current market players. I don't want my PC to be owned by Google or Apple. Maybe if another player like Purism were to come up with a convergent device where I could have a desktop computer (Linux of course) and just unplug and go with a mobile interface. I could get behind that.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-22 20:26

@Lvl999_MANGOs We appreciate you checking first. You're not breaking any rules posting memes here, but please keep in mind that we're a FOSS/Technology based Mastodon instance, so we while we don't require every single post to be about FOSS or technology in general, 500 posts an hour of cats with funny sayings isn't going to be content we appreciate as much. If you've got questions, check our CoC or ask one of the team.

https://hub.fosstodon.org/code-of-conduct

@kev @joseph @codesections @kelbot

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-22 17:45

@cooper Outside of it being decentralized, the fact that it's open source also protects our communities. Even if Gargron decides to take Mastodon in a direction the community doesn't agree with, it can always be forked. I love the protections this guarantees for everyone involved.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-22 16:58

@cooper That's a hard choice. I love it's decentralized nature. Watching the communities that are being broken up because of Google's shuttering of Google+, it's nice to know that a single corporation isn't making all the decisions about the future of the platform, and we'll never lose our communities because a corporation decides they're not making enough money off of us.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-22 16:51

@cooper Thanks so much. We really appreciate it! We're pretty proud of the community we've built here, and it's great to hear that others feel the same way!

I joined the fediverse in 2016 and used Mastodon for one day and forgot about it.

I tried to reset my password in 2017 and it didn't work.

I tried again in March of 2018 and it worked!

I have been a daily user since April 2018. I have met a lot of people, made some friends and started a few projects.

Thank you fediverse ‚ù§Ô∏è

#oneYearLater

@sarahtrieseverything Right? I can't say for certain that ActivityPub is the way of the future, but it's seeing support in a lot of social networks these days. Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-05 18:38

@Duder963 Depends on your interests. Did you check the Trunk?

Mike Stone @mike 2019-03-05 18:33

@colomar Oh, I seriously doubt it. Maybe something like the motor controllers, but that's a huge maybe. I think you'd probably have to gut the thing and pull everything out of it. Throw a Pi in there to run Mycroft and maybe if you're SUPER lucky you could control the motors through GPIO and kludge together a display driver. The Mark II has a graphical output, so Mycroft is developing a graphics layer. Getting it to work with Jibo hardware would be a whole other matter though.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-28 16:04

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-28 15:58

@ohyran All this stuff works well for power savings, but it's also good for home security. I have motion detecting cameras, and my lights work whether I'm home or not. This gives observers the impression that we're home even at times we're not, and I get notified of motion in my home when I'm not there. It's something that seems of questionable value when you don't have it, but when you do you grow to depend on.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-28 15:55

@ohyran Heh, it works for me. My alarm goes off in the morning, and it tells me when my kids' bus is going to arrive, reads me the latest news, and then turns on the lights in my livingroom, computer room, and bedroom (this last bit is so I don't go back to sleep). I have a hall light for my kids that turns on and off automatically when it's dark, and music for my youngers at bedtime that turns off automatically. My olders lights and network shut off too so they don't stay up to late.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-28 15:48

@tobybot11 Welcome aboard!

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-27 07:46

@codesections Yea, but those numbers are results from a developer survey, and emacs is used for more than coding. Also, consider the usage numbers from their 2015 survey, which showed emacs usage at 3.8%. I'm guessing that the usage numbers you're going to see for editors like vi(m) and emacs are going to fluctuate, maybe widely over the years. Still, they're mainstays of the environment, and I think they'll be around and "healthy" for years to come.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-27 07:37

@dugdun Ah, good deal. I didn't check the weather, but 10 degrees today in Colorado could have gone C or F. Either would have made perfect sense to me. I grew up in northern Montana, so I know what winters in less Phoenixy areas are like. I do miss the skiing.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-27 07:35

@neildarlow Yes, it's true! We CAN be taught!

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-27 02:44

@dugdun 10 is pretty chilly. I assume CO is Colorado? I'm in Arizona, but I use metrics because a lot of our community are international. My 20 is Celsius.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-27 02:40

@libregame It's fast. Really fast compared to other OSs on the same hardware. It'll browse the web and it has a version of LibreOffice. There is a limited catalog of software that will work on it. It's not the most stable system, but it is only beta. I'd recommend trying it for sure, but I wouldn't use it as a daily driver in it's current state. Your mileage may vary.

Thomas @possebaer 2019-02-19 20:57

#introductions

Hello, I am Thomas, I am a Linux User since Kernel 2.0.38. I started with SuSE (6.x?), used #debian, #fedora, #linuxfromscrath, but use now mainly @opensuse. I like tinkering around with my systems, which are routers with openwrt, a raspberry (raspbian), a linux sat receiver (openhdf), a vps (debian), lenovo thinkpad and a desktop system. I prefer using open source software, and to do self-hosting of services I use, but I am not overly dogmatic.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-19 21:52

@poetgrant I have no problem faulting them. It can be argued that they're not doing anything (conceptually) that wasn't being done 20 years ago, but 20 years ago there was not a single company tracking everywhere you go in the real world and almost everywhere you go on the Internet. Google especially, whose motto for years was "Don't Be Evil", knew what they were doing was above and beyond acceptable, but they did it anyway.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-19 15:05

@kelbot Yea, I used to work for a financial company up in Montana, and we had a delegation visit us one summer from Hawaii. They wanted to know what our "contingency plan" was for snow. That raised a few eyebrows in the room.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-19 15:03

@poetgrant How much of the Internet becomes unavailable in that scenario? And how are you to know which sites allow for tracking without being tracked? See, I don't have an issue with someone deciding to sell their privacy for a service. If they choose to do that and it's understood what they're doing, that's their call. My concern is when these companies are invisibly tracking user movements without their consent or knowledge, even when those users aren't using that company's services.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-19 14:52

@csharpner Not so much. You can create lists, but that's about the extent of it.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-19 14:50

@kelbot I've heard about that in the news. It's crazy. Add to that they're seeing snow in places it's rare, like Seattle, and even virtually unheard of, like Hawaii. We haven't gotten snow here, but they did down in Tucson. The only reason we haven't gotten any has been timing. We've had freezing temperatures some nights and rain others, but so far no moisture and freezing temps at the same time. Honestly, that would shut this city down.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-19 14:44

@poetgrant That's true to a certain extent, if you're actually using their products, but several of the #FAANG members also track and maintain extensive data about you even when you don't use their product. That is not because the user chose to use those services, but because site owners the users visits (invisibly) chose to use particular services. This tracking has become so extensive it's difficult to fully extricate yourself.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-19 14:28

This is the first year in close to a decade that I've been needing an ice scraper in my car. Almost every morning lately, the windows are frosted. Such a strange weather year.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-19 14:23

@michael I originally spent a lot of time over on Google+ too. I'm sad to see it go. There was a lot of potential there. I love it here. It reminds me of the early days of G+, only this time it's open source and federated, so no one can shut it down but the users.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-18 23:16

You can't pick up that conversation on the desktop like you can with Teams (or pretty much every single other app I can think of).

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-18 18:01

@shortcake@toot.style We just started using it at work too. I'd much rather be using something else. Mattermost, Rocket.chat, IRC, or even Slack. I do have to admit though, I Teams better than Skype, which is what we were using before. The bar wasn't set terribly high though.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-17 18:57

@kev Mine was less a question of the status quo and more a matter of convenience and capability. I started using Linux in the late 90s when I was going to college. I was studying Computer Science, and all our dev was done on Digital Unix. Having my own "Unix" was super attractive. Some friends of mine showed me a Mac running MKLinux, and I was sold. Free (as in beer) was a huge benefit too (I was broke). Free (as in Freedom) came later and is very important to me now.

@nolan @bobstechsite

@libregame Welcome aboard!

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-16 04:33

@colomar
I can do it, but I have to focus purely on the audio, otherwise it's background noise. The only time that works for me is when I'm doing something entirely mindless, like driving. If I'm doing something that requires even the slightest bit of concentration, I don't hear the audio. I've even found myself driving, listening to music, and thinking about something, where I will suddenly realize the music stopped without me noticing because I was THINKING about something.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-12 16:22

@ja_nishat It's an interesting idea, and I think it's entirely possible, but someone will have to release a product that makes self hosting easy. I picture a small device, maybe in the form factor of one of the Google Home Hubs (just in form) that will automatically interface with a registrar to setup the necessary internet stuff. Then there would need to be an easy migration integrated for hardware upgrades (similar to smart phones). Then all services would run on the single device.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-09 23:35

@hirnbrot@mstdn.io
That's an interesting comment, and I don't disagree despite the fact that I love IRC and have been using it for decades. I just wonder if it's a failing in IRC clients and not IRC itself. Because of its nature and age, there has been little to no attempts to hide the "nerdier" aspects of the system. If a client acted as an interpreter and made some of the more arcane components of IRC more understandable, I think it would achieve what you're thinking.

#introdcution
Hello Mastodon people! I'm new and very excited to be here!
I like the idea of how computing and now even social networking (thanks to mastodon) can be done better using open source ideology.
I'm a science enthusiast(esp. physics) and a mechanical engineering major, and always try to adopt open source ideology into my working field and academia.
I also think, science and education in general is done better through open source models.
Cheers!

Mike Stone @mike 2019-02-03 17:31

@aetios @clacke @kev Yep, and that's true in this case too. I should have been more specific. It was our load balancer. I don't know the specifics at this point. We'll hopefully get them tomorrow during our post mortem, but something about the change was telling the load balancer that our servers were offline even though they were up and running perfectly. Mike Stone @mike 2019-01-30 23:47

Maybe this is me, but how WEIRD is this script. This is real. I found this in our production environment today (with proprietary specifics removed of course).

#!/bin/bash

cd /some/directory

for file in *
do
gpg file.txt
rm file.txt

transfer ()
{
echo put $file..txt.pgp | sftp -b- user@host:/directory
echo $?
rm $file.pgp
}

transfer
done

How weird is it defining a function INSIDE OF A FOR LOOP??? Am I nuts or is that just WEIRD. SMH.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-01-29 17:01

@hund@linuxrocks.online No, it's not so much the application, it's the content. Well, it's kind of the application, sometimes. i3 is a very minimalist interface. Not much there to get in the way, so I want applications that I use in i3 to be the same. That's why traditionally I've wanted to use a browser like qute. Other apps like mplayer are also fine. But the web in particular is built in such a way that it doesn't feel like it's right in that kind of environment. It's just aesthetics, and me.

dansup the creator @dansup 2019-01-27 23:37

It is in our best interest as developers and users to work together in the fediverse.

Pixelfed is not competing with Mastodon or any other fedi project. The amount of MAU the whole fediverse has is under 1m users. A drop in the bucket compared to centralized, corporate, social media.

(MAU = Monthly Active Users)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_virtual_communities_with_more_than_100_million_active_users

Mike Stone @mike 2019-01-27 20:17

@jlelse@social.jlelse.me It does boot super fast, but one of the really nice things I've just been enjoying so much is suspending the laptop, close the lid, and it wakes up when you open the lid again. You're right back to work. It's fast to boot, but it's even faster waking up from suspended state. I love it. I've never been a big user of that feature before, but I can't say enough positive about it right now.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-01-27 19:30

@kev @rmdes On top of that, at least here at Fosstodon, we do implement a council of sorts. Kev and I are the instance admins, but we have a team of moderators that also are involved in decisions. Kev and I take many of the decisions we make to the moderators for discussion. Additionally, we'll take choices to the community at large if it's of significant importance. We want our community to be involved with the instance. It's theirs too.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-01-26 05:16

@dpreacher@mstdn.io
üòã Thinkpad is asleep before the Windows machine I told to sleep before sending a tooth on Fosstodon.

Order of events: (Windows box=wb, Thinkpad=to)

Wb: Go to sleep.
Tp: Wake from sleep.
Tp: Post status on Fosstodon.
Tp: Go to sleep.
Tp: Sleeps üò¥
Wb: Sleeps üò¥

Mike Stone @mike 2019-01-22 17:29

@mike@jergefelt.se @kev I've seen that. I had a similar experience when I was working at my University. Only in my case, I got a call from a prof claiming his computer was making a weird noise. When we got there, you could hear the read/write heads grinding on the platters. Total loss. Same story regarding backups and years of data. That guy plopped down in the middle of his office floor.

We took the hard drive apart later. The platters looked like someone played Frisbee with them in the parking lot.

@vincent 2019-01-22 06:16

Good news, everyone! #introductions

Taking my first steps in the Fediverse, and you are all invited to the party!

I've been using Linux (Debian and Arch) for 15+ years now, and am admin for a small corporate setup, based on #Kerberos, #OpenLdap, #NFS, #Asterisk, #BorgBackup. I also wrote my own matter management application for lawyers in #PHP, #Postgresql and #jQuery.

I'm Interested in server admin, networking, security and programming. By day I am a lawyer in a Belgian FMCG company.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-01-18 15:00

@AndrzejL If there was a Free option with good app support, I'd definitely go that route. So far that option hasn't appeared, but I keep my fingers crossed. Maybe as the market matures some Free players will make a dent. I've got my fingers crossed for the Librem 5. If they can get some support on the app side, I'll trade in my Android. 4/4

Mike Stone @mike 2019-01-18 14:58

@AndrzejL I'm swapping out my launcher for a 3rd party. I'm using a 3rd party email client and text messaging app. I can change the default apps. I can update the icon packs. I can make dramatic changes to how the phone works. Google isn't stopping me.

This is one of the many reasons I'll never own an Apple phone again. True, Google is monetizing watching what I'm doing, but at least their interference is minimal.

That's not to say I like it.

3/

Mike Stone @mike 2019-01-18 14:54

@AndrzejL I know that Google is monitoring everything I do and everywhere I go. People I interact with and web pages I view. But that's the catch for me. They're watching. They're not interfering in what I'm doing. It's a covert activity.

Apple's overbearing control of my device is very overt in my eyes, and it endlessly frustrates me when I'm forced to use one of their devices. I know it's a false sense, but I still feel like I have more ownership of a Google device. I have more control.

2/

Mike Stone @mike 2019-01-18 14:51

@AndrzejL See, this kicks off a whole new thing for me, and it's not specific to Apple. Despite popular belief, they don't sell you a phone. They let you use one of theirs for an indefinite amount of time. It may seem the same to a lot of people, but it's not.

Apple is worse than most when it comes to this "philosophy". They lock their devices down to the point it's obnoxious. iOS users can't even put an icon on the bottom ride side of the screen without filling every other slot first.

1/

[MOVED] Amolith @amolith 2019-01-17 02:11

I just got an email from Have I Been Pwned (#HIBP) saying that one of my email addresses was part of a recently revealed data breach.

"The unique email addresses totalled 772,904,991."
"There are 21,222,975 unique passwords."

https://www.troyhunt.com/the-773-million-record-collection-1-data-reach/

The article doesn't give many details about the breach itself, just how to use their products to protect yourself. I dislike that but this is still important to share in case someone is seriously affected by this breach.

codesections @codesections 2019-01-15 17:58

#dlarm, my CLI alarm system for #dwm, is now v0.2.0, which includes colorized output, testing, and a fix for an off-by-one error in the method it uses for guessing at less-than-ideal user input.
